reasoning:
The critique targets a real, load-bearing sub-claim in the essay’s anti-WAM-convergence argument under moral realism: that increased “distance/alienness” from current preferences makes de dicto moral motivation less likely. If that link were reversed or even substantially weakened, the essay’s pessimism about the realism case would be less supported, though the overall position wouldn’t collapse because the essay also argues from (i) externalism/internalism complications, (ii) anti-realism leading to divergence, (iii) blockers/lock-in, and (iv) threats and bargaining issues. Hence moderate centrality.

As an objection it has some force: history does provide examples where unfamiliar/transcendent doctrines motivate large sacrifices, so the essay arguably should have considered the possibility that “alien” moral truth could be motivationally compelling. But it doesn’t strongly refute the attacked claim because it gives only a plausibility argument and analogy, not reasons to expect this effect to dominate in the relevant setting (post-AGI reflection, varied agents, potential strategic avoidance of motivating beliefs, etc.). It also doesn’t engage the essay’s specific mechanisms (e.g., people choosing not to learn/endorse motivating moral facts under internalism, or believing but not acting under externalism), so it weakens rather than overturns.

Most statements are broadly reasonable (alienness can sometimes increase motivation; religious movements are evidence), but the implied general reversal (“alienness might increase motivation rather than decrease it”) is not established as typical, only as possible, so correctness is good but not perfect. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little extraneous material.
title: Alien moral truths might increase motivation through transcendence rather than decrease it
